bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul H. Streit, November 13, 1952

div1.p: Hench is delighted to know that Streit has accepted the Cuban invitation to come to the Camp Lazear dedication. He warns Streit that the preservation of Camp Lazear has been a politically sensitive issue. Hench thinks it is important that the Americans are appreciative, but also truthful, about what happened at Camp Lazear. He laments that Building No. 1 has been almost completely torn down in the process of repairing it.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul H. Streit, November 13, 1952
div1.opener:
November 13, 1952
Major General Paul H. Streit
Commanding General
Walter Reed Army Hospital
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Streit:
div1.p:
I am delighted to know that you have accepted the Cuban invitation to go
to Havana and the dedication of Camp Lazear. As I told you, there is
some question as to whether they calling it Camp Lazear or renaming it
Parque Finlay.

I am very glad that you are going, but I must warn you that I thing you
will give more than you will got. By that I mean that I do not anticipate
an elaborate, impressive ceremony with all of Cuba's officialdom present
and with the usual banquets, etc. I may be mistaken but after twelve
years of discussion with my Cuban friends, I have found that Camp Lazear
has been made something of a political football by various factions.
There are sincere groups in Cuba that are just as eager as I am to see
the proper memorialization of Camp Lazear, who are disappointed with what
the present “ins” are doing and who may actually not attend the ceremony.
But your presence and the presence of other Americans may do much to heal
the unfortunate wounds which began 50 years ago when, according to the
Cubans, the Rockefeller Foundation and the U. S. Army insisted on giving
most of the credit to Reed and little to Finlay. As you know, they re-
acted violently to the extent that Reed's name has been vilified for years
in Cuba and although there are a few memorials to Lazear and others, there
is not a single one to Reed. This will be the first.

Although they have not done what I wanted and although Reed and his col-
leagues may once more be over-shadowed by the homage to Finlay, at least
it is a modest beginning. To that extent I am pleased and feel that we
must show our due appreciation, perhaps even in excessive language, more, actually,
then we feel. Nevertheless, as I said over the phone, any Americans present
there, who may speak although we can pay great tribute to Finlay, must keep
the record clear and tell exactly what did happen at Camp Lazear.

I may have misadvised you in suggesting that you may be called upon to
make some informal remarks somewhere along the line but from my experience
in Cuba, I suspect you will; however before spending much time and effort
in this talk, I would suggest that you write or wire your host about this
matter. But even if he suggests that you will not be called upon, I still
think you had better have a few thoughts collected in case you are suddenly
called upon at a dinner or some other meeting or by the Cuban press.

Permit me to enclose a reprint which will refresh your mind on certain
details and which will show how the little building looked four years
ago. I regret to say that they have almost completely torn it down and
made a restoration rather than a repair job. Also, to show you the dif-
ficulties in which I have been placed, permit me to send you copies of
two letters which I sent to Doctor Nogueira some months ago with some
interesting newspaper clippings which will show you the attitude which I
fear we will have to face politely and not aggressively.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Enclosures
P.S.: I just received the enclosed.
